childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1989-2001

You were born the year the Berlin Wall came down and The Simpsons became a weekly series—two events that, in their own ways, would define the cultural landscape for the next three decades. George H.W. Bush had just taken office. The Cold War was ending. The Exxon Valdez had just spilled 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound, which should have been a warning about everything to come.

Your childhood was the last gasp of a world before the internet swallowed everything. You had a landline, probably with a cord long enough to stretch into your bedroom for privacy. You rented movies from Blockbuster on Friday nights. You learned your multiplication tables from a laminated poster, not an app. Saturday mornings were sacred—cartoons were appointment viewing, not on-demand content.

You were five when Princess Diana separated from Prince Charles, seven when she died. You were nine during Columbine, which turned school into something you practiced surviving. You were twelve on September 11th, 2001—old enough to understand the planes hitting the towers, young enough for it to reshape your understanding of safety forever.

Technology arrived in waves. Your family's first computer probably ran Windows 95 or 98. You used Encarta for school reports before Wikipedia existed. You might have had a pager, then a Nokia brick phone, then a Razr if you were lucky. AOL Instant Messenger was your first social network, and your away messages were embarrassingly profound.

Your childhood was analog enough to remember what boredom felt like, and digital enough to watch it disappear.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Millennials

You're a Millennial, born between 1981 and 1996 according to Pew Research. That makes you part of roughly 72 million Americans who get blamed for killing industries, eating too much avocado toast, and somehow both being lazy and working multiple jobs to survive.

The defining moment for your generation was 9/11. You were twelve. Old enough to watch the towers fall on live television, young enough for that footage to be burned into your developing brain forever. The pre-9/11 world—the one where you could walk someone to their airport gate, where 'threat level' wasn't a daily vocabulary word—feels like ancient history now.

Your generation graduated into the 2008 financial crisis. The economy cratered right when you needed it to hold you up. Entry-level jobs vanished. The social contract your parents described—work hard, stay loyal, and you'll be rewarded—turned out to be a fairy tale. You've spent your adult life adapting to systems designed to extract maximum productivity for minimum compensation.

You're sandwiched between Gen X, who secured their bags before the economy imploded, and Gen Z, who arrived after the bag was already gone and adjusted expectations accordingly. You remember when optimism was reasonable. That memory makes the current reality sting more.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year Tim Burton's Batman redefined superhero movies and Field of Dreams made every adult man cry about their father. Driving Miss Daisy won Best Picture, which tells you a lot about what Hollywood thought was important in 1989. Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade gave us Sean Connery as Harrison Ford's dad, which was objectively perfect casting.

Musically, 1989 was the year Bobby Brown told everyone his prerogative wasn't their concern. Madonna released 'Like a Prayer' and set things on fire in the music video. Fine Young Cannibals had two number-one hits, which is more than most people remember. New Kids on the Block were inescapable—boy band culture was being invented in real time, setting the template for your middle school years.

Television in 1989 launched The Simpsons as a proper series, which would become the longest-running American animated program ever. Seinfeld debuted, though nobody noticed for a few years. Cops started airing, pioneering the reality TV format that would eventually consume network television entirely.

Your childhood pop culture was peak Nickelodeon—Doug, Rugrats, All That. Your pre-teen years belonged to TRL and whoever Carson Daly was pointing at that week. High school meant emo bangs, MySpace top 8 drama, and carefully curated playlists that said exactly who you were (or who you wanted to be).

You grew up before streaming, before algorithms, before content was infinite and attention was the scarcest resource. You waited for things. Anticipated things. Cared about premiere dates. That patience was good training for never getting what you were promised.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web. Not the internet—that already existed as a government research project. The web, specifically. The thing with links and pages and eventually cat videos. You are exactly as old as the modern internet, which is either poetic or alarming.

The Game Boy launched in 1989, the same year as you. You grew up with Tetris, then Pokémon, then whatever mobile game is currently demanding your attention. Portable entertainment evolved alongside you.

You were six when Windows 95 came out and the Start button became universal. Nine when Google launched. Eleven when Napster proved that music could be free if you didn't mind breaking the law. Fourteen when the iTunes Store made paying for songs feel reasonable again. Eighteen when the iPhone arrived and obliterated every assumption about what a phone was supposed to do.

This puts you in a specific technological position: digital native but analog-adjacent. You remember rotary phones but grew up with cordless. You learned to type on keyboards, not touchscreens. You can troubleshoot your parents' computer and explain TikTok to your younger cousins—the generational translator nobody asked for but everyone needs.

You witnessed the transition in real-time. You remember dial-up, then DSL, then broadband, then fiber. You remember when loading a single image took thirty seconds, and now you're annoyed when 4K video buffers. Your expectations scaled with the technology. That's made you both patient and impossibly demanding, depending on the context.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were born the year the Berlin Wall fell. November 9, 1989—people with hammers and pickaxes dismantled the symbol of Cold War division while the world watched. You don't remember it, obviously. You were either not born yet or a few months old. But that's the world you arrived in: one where the defining conflict of your parents' generation had just ended.

The Soviet Union collapsed when you were two. Communism as a global threat was already a memory by the time you started forming memories. Your anxieties would be different—terrorism, climate change, economic precarity—but the nuclear fear that defined the Boomer childhood was background noise at most.

You were five during the Oklahoma City bombing. Eight during Princess Diana's death, which you might remember as the first time you saw adults collectively mourn a stranger. You were nine when Columbine happened, transforming schools into places where you practiced hiding under desks and staying quiet.

September 11th, 2001, you were twelve. Seventh grade, probably. You watched the towers fall on classroom televisions. The forever wars started that fall and continued for the next twenty years—your entire adolescence and young adulthood were backdropped by conflicts that never seemed to end.

You were nineteen during the 2008 financial crisis. Either in college watching your career prospects evaporate, or just entering the worst job market in decades. You were thirty when COVID-19 arrived, shutting down the world and teaching everyone how to be alone together.

By any measure, you've lived through more destabilizing historical events than any generation since the Greatest Generation. The difference is they got the GI Bill and cheap housing afterward. You got side hustles and student loan debt.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

If you followed the traditional timeline—high school at 18, college at 22, job search immediately after—you graduated into the 2008 financial crisis or its toxic aftershocks. Entry-level positions required three years of experience. Internships were unpaid. The phrase 'gig economy' was rebranded exploitation, and you were told to be grateful for it.

You're the generation that normalized job-hopping, not because you're disloyal but because companies abandoned loyalty first. The pension your grandparents received? Fantasy. The forty-year career at one company? History. You learned that corporations would lay you off the moment it helped their quarterly earnings, so treating them as anything other than transactional seemed naive.

You've worked in open-plan offices designed to foster collaboration and actually fostering nothing but distraction. You've endured 'unlimited vacation' policies that nobody uses because the culture punishes taking time off. You've sat through mandatory fun and team-building exercises that made you question your life choices.

The pandemic normalized remote work, which felt like a silver lining until employers decided that working from home meant working from everywhere, all the time. You proved you could do your job without a commute, and the reward was the expectation that you'd also do your job at 9 PM, on weekends, and during what used to be your lunch break.

Your career has been defined by adaptation. Pivoting. Upskilling. The credentials that got you hired are already obsolete. The skills that will matter in ten years don't exist yet. You're running on a treadmill that keeps speeding up, and nobody's offering a stop button.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You came of age during the dating app revolution. Tinder launched when you were twenty-four, which means you've experienced both meeting people organically and treating romance like a card game where you swipe left or right. You're the bridge generation—old enough to remember asking for someone's number in person, young enough to have your thumb reflexively swipe on photos.

You probably met at least one significant partner online, which your grandparents find confusing and Gen Z finds completely unremarkable. You've navigated the anxieties specific to digital communication: read receipts, response timing, the paralyzing analysis of what a three-letter text actually means.

Your generation texted more than called, but you still remember calling. You understand the phone as a voice-transmission device, not just a text and app delivery system. You've had conversations that lasted hours and conversations that were just a string of emoji.

Millennials delayed marriage longer than any previous generation. Not because you don't value partnership but because weddings cost $30,000, houses cost half a million dollars, and your student loans are still accruing interest. The traditional life timeline your parents followed isn't available in your price range.

You've maintained long-distance relationships because everyone moved for work, for school, for somewhere they could afford rent. Friendships happen in group chats across time zones. You know how to be present with people who are physically absent and absent with people who are physically present. That's the paradox of connection in your generation.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were eleven when the dot-com bubble burst, which seemed abstract at the time. You were nineteen during the 2008 financial crisis, which was not abstract at all. That was supposed to be your launch pad decade, and instead it was a crater. You've watched the economy collapse twice before turning thirty-five, with a pandemic recession thrown in for variety.

Your relationship with money is defined by having less of it than you were promised. You did everything right—got the degree, worked the internships, networked, optimized—and the reward was a job market that treated you as disposable. The path to middle-class stability that your parents walked had been dismantled by the time you arrived.

You save obsessively because you've seen how fast stability disappears. You invest because Social Security might not exist when you need it, and you don't trust it anyway. The stock market feels like a casino, but not playing is guaranteed loss, so you play. You've learned financial literacy not because you wanted to but because nobody else was going to manage this mess for you.

The wealth gap between you and previous generations is staggering. Boomers controlled 21% of national wealth at your age. Millennials control 7%. They bought houses for $100,000 that are now worth $500,000. You're being told to skip the lattes while they refinance their third property.

Financial success for your generation has been redefined. It's not a white picket fence—it's paying rent in a city where the jobs are. It's not early retirement—it's hoping you can retire at all. The metrics changed, and nobody updated the expectations that were placed on you.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your generation's greatest strength is also its greatest vulnerability: you believe in systems. You think if you just find the right approach, the right optimization, the right life hack, you can navigate around the structural problems that define your era. Sometimes you can. Often you can't, but you keep trying because the alternative is despair.

You've adapted to dysfunction so thoroughly that you've forgotten to demand better. Precarious employment, unaffordable healthcare, crushing student debt—you've normalized these as conditions of existence rather than policy failures that could be fixed. You've gotten very good at coping, which has made you less good at demanding change.

You're conflict-averse in ways that hurt you. You were trained to be collaborative, team-oriented, solution-focused. These are good traits, but they're also easy to exploit. You'll work unpaid overtime for exposure. You'll accept equity instead of salary. You'll absorb abuse from toxic bosses because the job market is brutal and you need health insurance.

Your irony is a defense mechanism that sometimes prevents genuine engagement. You can't just enjoy things—you have to enjoy them ironically, or critically, or with a layer of protective distance. This makes sincerity feel dangerous and advocacy feel embarrassing. You hedge everything, including your own needs.

You're chronically online in ways that feel like engagement but often aren't. You can mobilize for causes on social media, but changing policy requires showing up to city council meetings, which is boring and offline. Digital activism scratches the itch without actually addressing the problem. You've confused performance with participation.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (2009-2019): You came of age during the Great Recession's aftermath. Jobs were scarce, then scarce with extra steps. You moved back home or crammed into apartments with multiple roommates. You took positions you were overqualified for and called them 'opportunities.' The life milestones your parents hit by 25—marriage, house, career track—kept getting pushed back. This decade was supposed to be about building foundation. Instead, it was about survival.

Your 30s (2019-2029): You're in this decade now. A pandemic arrived right at the start, which felt about right. You're probably earning more than you did at 25, but inflation ate most of the difference. You're either settling into something that resembles stability or actively resisting the pressure to settle for something that doesn't satisfy you. Kids, house, long-term partnership—some people have these, many don't, and the judgment from older generations hasn't stopped. This is the decade where you're supposed to have figured things out. Most of you are still figuring.

Your 40s (2029-2039): Statistically, this should be your peak earning decade. You'll have seniority, if seniority still matters by then. Your kids, if you have them, will be school-age or older. Your parents will be aging, adding caretaker responsibilities to everything else on your plate. You'll be sandwiched between generations, managing everyone else's crises while your own needs wait. This is the decade where you either commit to the life you've built or tear it down and start over.

Your 50s (2039-2049): You'll have lived through at least four economic crises and probably another pandemic (statistically likely). Climate change will have made certain places unlivable. Technology will be unrecognizable from what you grew up with. You'll be approaching retirement age without the financial security that word used to imply. You'll mentor younger workers who don't understand why you're so shaped by 2008, and you'll be annoyed at their assumptions the same way Boomers annoyed you.

Your 60s and beyond (2049+): Retirement in any traditional sense probably won't be available. You'll work part-time, consult, do gig economy tasks well past the age your grandparents retired. Social Security might exist in some form, but don't count on it. You'll tell younger generations about life before smartphones, before ubiquitous internet, before AI changed everything. They won't believe you. The world will be different in ways neither you nor anyone else can currently predict. That's always been true, but it's more true now.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 4 million people born in 1989. The Millennial generation overall is about 72 million Americans, making it the largest generation until Gen Z overtakes it in the coming years.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980), you're more educated—and more indebted because of it. Gen X got into the housing market before prices exploded. They got stable jobs before stable jobs became rare. They inherited a functional economy and proceeded to pull up the ladder. They complain about younger generations' work ethic while benefiting from policies that made their success possible.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), the wealth disparity is obscene. Boomers controlled over 21% of national wealth at your current age. Millennials control about 7%. Boomers paid for college with summer jobs. You took on mortgage-sized debt for the same degrees. Boomers bought houses for a few times their annual salary. You're lucky if you can afford the down payment on a condo that costs seven times yours.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012), you're similar but shaped by different traumas. You remember a pre-9/11 world, however faintly. They don't. You believed the system could be reformed. They assume it can't and are building around it. You learned to use smartphones. They've never known life without them. You have hope, buried under cynicism. They have cynicism, occasionally interrupted by hope.

Your life expectancy is 78-80 years, slightly lower than previous generations due to rising rates of 'deaths of despair'—suicide, overdose, alcohol-related disease. Your mental health outcomes are worse than any American generation on record. You're more anxious, more depressed, more medicated. The world you inherited was harder than the one promised to you.

But you're also more tolerant, more educated, and more aware of systemic injustice than generations before. You've normalized therapy. You've pushed for equity. You've made the world more inclusive even as it became less affordable. That tension—between progress and precarity—is the defining characteristic of your generation.

year_events: Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web
The Simpsons premiered as a full series
